Furan: Mechanisms of Formation and Levels in Food
Furan: Mechanisms of Formation
and Levels in Food

Don S. Forsyth, Adam Becalski, Valerie Casey, Steve Seaman,Karen Pepper and Samuel Ben Rejeb, Food Research Division, Bureau of Chemical Safety, Food Directorate, Health Canada
Don S. Forsyth, Adam Becalski, Valerie Casey, Steve
Seaman,Karen Pepper and Samuel Ben Rejeb, Food
Research Division, Bureau of Chemical Safety, Food
Directorate, Health Canada

Health Santé Canada Canada
Health Santé
Canada Canada

Background • Late March, 2004- Health Canada informed of US FDA investigation of furan in canned and bottled food commodities
Background
• Late March, 2004- Health Canada informed of US
FDA investigation of furan in canned and bottled
food commodities

• Furan has been shown to be carcinogenic in mice and rats, classified as “possibly carcinogenic to humans” (Group 2B) by IARC in 1995
• Furan has been shown to be carcinogenic in mice
and rats, classified as “possibly carcinogenic to
humans” (Group 2B) by IARC in 1995

• Although furan is used in industrial processes the
• Although furan is used in industrial processes the

likely source was considered to be formation during food processing
likely source was considered to be formation
during food processing

• April, 2004- Health Canada commenced method
• April, 2004- Health Canada commenced method

development for study of mechanism(s) of formation and survey of Canadian food products
development for study of mechanism(s) of
formation and survey of Canadian food products

Health Santé Canada Canada
Health Santé
Canada Canada

Furans in Foods
Furans in Foods

• Furan derivatives have been reported in a wide variety of foods and are a significant flavour and odour component in coffee, cocoa, and various cooked meat products
• Furan derivatives have been reported in a
wide variety of foods and are a significant
flavour and odour component in coffee,
cocoa, and various cooked meat products

• Furan has been found in coffee, canned
• Furan has been found in coffee, canned

beef, sodium caseinate, soy and rapeseed protein and caramel
beef, sodium caseinate, soy and rapeseed
protein and caramel

Health Santé Canada Canada
Health Santé
Canada Canada

Possible Mechanisms of Formation
Possible Mechanisms of
Formation

• Thermal degradation of carbohydrates
• Thermal degradation of carbohydrates

(Maillard reaction)
(Maillard reaction)

• Thermal oxidation of lipid
• Thermal oxidation of lipid

• Decomposition of ascorbic acid or its
• Decomposition of ascorbic acid or its

derivatives
derivatives

Health Santé
Canada Canada

Analytical Methods
Analytical Methods

Two methods were used:
Two methods were used:

1. Static Headspace Analysis
1. Static Headspace Analysis

– Mechanism(s) of formation and food survey
– Mechanism(s) of formation and food survey

2. MicroExtraction Technique (MET)- A SPME related method developed at Health Canada – Food survey
2. MicroExtraction Technique (MET)- A SPME
related method developed at Health Canada
– Food survey

Mechanism of Formation Studies
Mechanism of Formation Studies

• 10 mg of test compound was added to a
• 10 mg of test compound was added to a

• Cooled to 4°C

Conclusions
Conclusions

Two pathways of furan formation were identified in the model systems:
Two pathways of furan formation were
identified in the model systems:

1. Polyunsaturated fatty acids (linoleic, linolenic) via peroxidation and ring closure
1. Polyunsaturated fatty acids (linoleic,
linolenic) via peroxidation and ring
closure

2. Decomposition of ascorbic acid
2. Decomposition of ascorbic acid

derivatives particularly dehydroascorbic acid and isoascorbic acid
derivatives particularly dehydroascorbic
acid and isoascorbic acid

Next Steps?
Next Steps?

• Further studies on mechanism(s) of formation using model systems and precursor fortified food matrices
• Further studies on mechanism(s) of
formation using model systems and
precursor fortified food matrices

• Losses of furan during food processing
• Losses of furan during food processing

• Further surveys of canned and bottled
• Further surveys of canned and bottled

and cooking
and cooking

products
products

• Participate in round robin method
• Participate in round robin method

validation study
validation study

• Update health risk assessment as new
• Update health risk assessment as new

data becomes available
data becomes available
